Author: SHossain#0007
Content: i have the chains up. they will keep running

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: we are still at block 0. best thing about this is no mining needed

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: its very fast to sync the chain! as it has no blocks

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if these were 1kb datablobs, the 10 million of them would be 10GB in less than an hour

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 2TB per week. just not practical to store all that data

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: there are DC that gives unlimited bandwidth with 100MB/s

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: tomorrow i will add realtime joining, so hopefully a new node can jump in to a 5k/sec blast and get 100% of the packets

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: OVH also does that with faster speed i guess on some of their servers

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: ok, plz coordinate with server operators so we can verify performance across many different geolocations

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: by this time tomorrow, i should have realtime joining working, that will make things much smoother as it wont be required to be coordinated when to join

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a single "chain" could support many video broadcasts in parallel

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: cool. we can set a date for the next mass public test. i'll post in #notarynode  #kmdlabs and maybe in #officialüì¢ channels for any interested participants with required knowledge to join

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and with realtime joining, basically you can have arbitrary number of such chains, each one being like a different channel you can tune into.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it really just needs a passive follower node

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i guess being able to run a blaster would be good too, so that can be spread out across N nodes

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: did you notice the numbers are going down now? üôÇ

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: purging from memory

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: every second

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, it purges from memory 59 minutes ago to make room for the next second

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this is what allows it to reuse the same memory in a circular buffer

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: each second is actually an openhashtable, so there is a circular buffer of 3600 hashtables and in realtime it is switching from one to the next

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: most all computations are in constant time

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: the numbers are matching on both nodes as they are being purged

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes since 100% of the 9million are in sync, then each seconds data would also be in sync

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: only searching the hashtables for packets is a linear search, but that is once per second to scan through 8192 spots. not a big amount of computing

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i estimate each 100 tx/sec will use up 1% of a core, though with this last test it was much better than that

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: of course, this is just the lowest level transport and it isnt doing anything with the data. any time needed for processing the data will be in addition, but do that in a different core and nothing slows down

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: somehow it is stable doing overlapped rpc calls, and it has no locks internally

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: very happy with its performance

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: it was an adrenaline filled test today üôÇ

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: yesterday was just getting warmed up

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: but, those 100 or 30 instances on a single server lead to hub and spoke kinda networking. better result is achieved with running a single daemon on a single server
